B000002U82|5.0|'Dark Side of the Moon' marks the point where Pink Floyd were catapulted from being a decent size rock/psychadelic band with a healthy following, into the realms of musical immortality. This album is an astonishing and groundbreaking achievement in terms of both its musical, and lyrical content. <br /> <br />Musically there is no band that is as mind-blowing as Pink Floyd and 'Dark Side of the Moon' is where they had fully honed their talents. The opening track 'Speak To Me' fades in on a combination of a heartbeat, footsteps, random voices and a cacophany of bells. This heady blend prepares the listener for the eclecticism that is to follow. The song that is perhaps musically the most astonishing is 'The Great Gig in the Sky'. Completely devoid of any lyrics it is given its power and passion by the beautiful but harrowing voice of Clare Torry. This track certainly ranks among the most inspired and breathtaking from the extensive Pink Floyd repertoire. <br /> <br />Lyrically this album is also very impressive with a maturity and wisdom that the band are famous for. The lyrics show a dis-satisfaction with adult life in tracks such as 'Breathe' and 'Time'. Roger Waters reflects and proclaims in his lyrics \\"Run rabbit run/Dig that hole, forget the sun/And when at last, the work is done/Don't sit down it's time to start another one\\". Lyrics such as these would appear to suggest that the album is gloomy and unpleasant. However this is not the case. The musical abilities of the band lend these lyrics a sort of tragic beauty. <br /> <br />Although it is somewhat of a cliche to say that every music lover must own this album, it is also a fact. Such a phenomenal piece of music comes along only once or twice a decade and these days, they appear to be getting fewer and further between.

B000AP04MO|5.0|In this chronicle of a tempestuous marriage, told in a series of flashbacks, that takes place entirely on the couple's road trips in France, director Stanley Donen shows us a  more adult, complex Audrey Hepburn than we usually see on film. She and Albert Finney play Joanna and Mark, a chic British couple, who quarrel their way across France in a variety of wonderful, compact European cars during their twelve year marriage. Since they both take turns driving during the course of the film, it's clear that this is a marriage where no one person is in the \\"driver's seat\\"--this is a marriage that (despite Mark's boorish behavior) is based on equality. The fact that they're usually in tiny cars also signifies the sometimes claustrophobic intimacy they experience with each other.<br /><br /> Joanna and Mark argue their way around a long-gone France, that has little traffic and a bucolically undisturbed countryside. But Mark's an architect with a wealthy French client, whose developments will destroy the pastoral rural areas that he and Joanna equate with the beginnings of their relationship. Both the countryside and their marriage have lost their original purity and innocence. Mark is a blowhard who is constantly making arrogant claims for himself, but he continuously looses his passport, which Joanna always manages to quietly retrieve. She is the one who really anchors his identity, and the fact that underneath his arrogant facade, he realizes it and loves her for it, gives the film its emotional depth.<br /><br />An added bonus is Hepburn's charming mid-sixties \\"mod\\" wardrobe. I particularly liked the  dress made out of what looked like little mirrors that she wears towards the end of the film (how'd she get that in her suitcase?) and the Courreges dress and bug-eyed sunglasses she wears in the final scene. Highly recommended.

0790729350|5.0|The Summer of 1969 seems a thousand years ago.  I was eighteen years old, had just graduated from high school, was on vacation in Hawaii with my family, and terrified of the draft because the Vietnam War was at its height. <br /> <br />Watching Michael Wadleigh's Oscar-winning documentary, WOODSTOCK: 3 DAYS OF PEACE & MUSIC (1970), on letterboxed double videocassette, I don't know how I survived that Summer of 1969.  For those of us not gathered in a field in upstate New York over one weekend, the movie is a priceless cultural record of an era.  No one got killed, and at least one person was born.  The crowd size was estimated at 500,000, with minimal toilets and highways turned into parking lots.  At one point, mention is made that \\"This is the third largest city in New York\\".  Fences were broken down, so some people got in to the musical concert for free.  People were making love in fields--it was called \\"balling\\" in that long ago era.  There was nudity elsewhere as people washed their only clothes in a muddy river.  Maybe because there was so much drug use, almost everyone was too stoned to be unruly or unhappy.  There was a loudspeaker announcement that some of \\"the pot\\" was bad.  \\"Use it at your own risk, people.\\"  Wadleigh, at least five camera operators, and a huge team of editors (including Martin Scorsese and his future collaborator Thelma Schoonmaker) brilliantly employ split screen to show the crowd trying to get in by any means possible and the owners of the land talking about the kids; their opinions naturally vary.  Certainly, it was difficult to helicopter in medical supplies and food for half a million people.  But through it all, everyone survived and seemed to have an adventurous time.  And now everyone can see it all on home video in their homes or apartments, whether they were there or not. <br /> <br />Originally just titled WOODSTOCK, the movie ran 184 minutes.  But now it is called WOODSTOCK: 3 DAYS OF PEACE & music and runs a whopping 225 minutes.  The 40 minute running time difference is mostly music performances, making this maybe the greatest concert film of all time.  Included over nearly four hours, often in split-screen Panavision and Dolby Surround Stereo, are three numbers by Crosby, Stills & Nash, two songs by Richie Havens, \\"Joe Hill\\" and \\"Swing Low Sweet Chariot\\" by Joan Baez, The Who doing an enthralling number from \\"Tommy\\", Sha-Na-Na doing \\"At the Hop\\", Joe Cocker and the Grease Band, Country Joe and the Fish, Arlo Guthrie, Two Years After, Jefferson Airplane doing two songs not in the theatrical cut, John Sebastian, a song by Country Joe McDonald,  Santana, Sly and the Family Stone, Janis Joplin in a song cut from the original film, and Jimi Hendrix ending the weekend with three numbers (one cut before), including \\"The Star-Spangled Banner\\" on an acoustic guitar.  It is one mindsucker of a musical lineup. <br /> <br />To especially watch The Director's Cut of WOODSTOCK and in one evening is to be grateful that Michael Wadleigh, his camera people, and his editors  put up with inconveniences galore over this 1969 Summer weekend.  They have captured, now and forever, what one aspect of that drugs and sex era was like for 500,000 attendees.  And they have preserved on film for the rest of America--and maybe the world--what Woodstock was like as a concert event.  Set aside a weekend and watch this almost-four hour musical masterpiece.  (REVIEWED ON LETTERBOXED VIDEOCASSETTE). <br /> <br />
B000G759LW|5.0|Just like one of the songs on her album, she's here to stay! After almost a 4 year break from her last album, \\"Stripped\\", Christina comes back with a vengeance with \\"Back To Basics\\".  <br /> <br />Unlike most pop stars who produce mediocre stuff a year after their last album for the sake of new material, Christina is truly in a class of her own! You can tell a lot of effort went into each track. What's even better is that there's 2 discs worth of material, with great tracks on each. Disc 1 offers her current hit, \\"Ain't No Other Man\\", with it's great throwback to 1940's style jamming done in a modern style. \\"Without You\\", a haunting ballad which showcases Christina's beautiful God-given voice and \\"Here To Stay\\" is a sassy number proving she's no late 90's teenybopper pop star and proves she has staying power. <br /> <br />Disc 2 offers even more great songs. \\"Candyman\\" is probably the catchiest song on both discs, with a great chorus and great beat that's sure to get you hopping around. \\"Welcome\\" sounds like something you'd hear at a circus, with it's great melody and dramatic lyrics. \\"Hurt\\" can be considered the album's \\"Beautiful\\" (her hit song from 2002).  <br /> <br />Both discs are 20's, 30's and 40's-inspired songs that are both classy and listenable. <br /> <br />Next to Pharrell and Beyonc's new albums, you gotta go pick this great album up now! Christina's come a LONG way from her \\"Genie In A Bottle\\" days. It truly shows in \\"Back To Basics\\".

B0000657UB|4.0|This CD is reproduced from the LP of one of the very first folk rock groups that drew directly from English-Irish-Scot lineage. On it is a rousing rendition of the ill-fated & adulterous affair of the farmhand Matty Groves with the Lady of the House; an atmospheric version of the vampire Reynardine leading his victim over the misty mountain; and the intiguing Tam Lin, with a text replete with alchemical-like references. The rock backup music is a bit primitive judging by today's standards, but there's charm in the simplicity. Highly recommended for the folk/ethnic music connoisseur. Oh yes--the bonus track Sir Patrick Spens is a wonderful folk ballad. Sandy Denny's purist vocals provides the perfect delivery for this material.
0393061434|4.0|First of all, I'm one of the longtime Apple faithful, an early Apple II user and an original 128K Mac purchaser. I've been waiting months for this book to be released.    I must agree with an earlier reviewer who felt the book seems to have been written for a younger audience. Based on many, many hours of recorded transcripts and personal interviews, it has a folksy, easygoing style, as if Wozniak is reciting a long story to one of his kids. It's effective, though, because the work is pretty much a long, personal narrative.    Loved the \\"engineer as an artist\\" metaphor. Wozniak's designs certainly rate amongst the computer world's historical best, no doubt about it. I only wish he had touched on the Macintosh vs. the 'bread and butter' Apple II marketing struggle just a bit. Or, perhaps, how a model of the IIgs bore his name and autograph.    Or, after moving down from the hills to a place off Shannon Road, he picked one of the hottest (degrees F) canyon views in the LG area and customized his home with underground children's caverns and dinosaur playrooms.    I quite enjoyed the book. I also understand why Steve Jobs was reticent to pen the foreword, though. He'll never get over not having the ID badge of Apple Employee #1.

B000FTWB7G|5.0|\\"The Open Door\\" is hard to digest at first given that half of the creative team that made Fallen a great album are long gone. In my personal opinion, it was for the better. At first listen, it became apparent that Amy was held back by Ben Moody. While Fallen was more catchy and mainstream, The Open Door is more experimental, heavier and better musically. The songs are more epic and contain a ton of gothic overtones that makes this a album that could be playing at Halloween this year. Songs like \\"Snow White Queen\\", \\"Lacrymosa\\", \\"Cloud Nine\\" are creepy and eerie sounding in a good way. \\"Like You\\" is about the passing of Amy's sister written in a child's perspective. The lyrics, melody and of course, her voice makes this the most haunting and best track she ever recorded. The album kicks off with the heavy \\"Sweet Sacrifice\\" which has a very catchy melody but overall it could've been a bit longer than just 3 minutes. \\"Call Me When You're Sober\\", the first single, is up next. Even though that song doesn't fit well with the rest of the songs, its still a great showcase of Amy's powerful voice. \\"Lithium\\" is said to be the next single and I'm positive it will be a big hit. The choir and strings appear once more in \\"Your Star\\" followed by the final rocking track \\"All That I'm Living For\\". Then comes the standout track, the beautiful ballad \\"Good Enough\\", which is the first time in the hour that a upbeat \\"happy\\" song appears. A great way to end this album after all the painful but empowering journey that Amy has been through. I suggest people who did not like this album right away to give it a few more listens to see how great it really is. Amy and guitarist Terry have created something wonderful here and I just hope her fans see that.
1591840562|5.0|What a great read this book is! It can be read just for the fun of understanding Kawasaki's personality, his open approach to business, or it can be read as a primer of how to really start that business. Obviously the man's words are well field-tested and there are many practical suggestions that really cut to the bone and make you stop and rethink a strategy. <br /> <br />But, let's say, you don't want to start a business that requires investors and venture capitalists. Say, you don't have the time, the financial wherewithal or grand plan that requires these things. Then the book to read is \\"Internet Riches\\", by Scott Fox. Let's say you take Kawasaki's ideas to heart and you want to \\"make meaning\\" in your life and/or \\"make the world a better place\\" and increase the quality of your life or others, but you have little money. Should this stop you? Do you need venture capitalists?  <br /> <br />In \\"Internet Riches\\" Fox challenges you to find what makes meaning for you. There are exercises to discover your particular niche, plus many life stories of people like yourself. You can relate to this book if you are in Podunk or L.A., and then he mentors you through all the start up stages. It is very hands-on and a useful handbook for entrepreneurs. And guess what? you can afford to do it. <br /> <br />Taken together these two books are a great complement to each other. The \\"Art of the Start\\" will get you in the mood with great theoretical underpinnings, the \\"Internet Riches\\" shows you how to do it now, with strategic and practical ideas.

0761129235|5.0|This book is a valuable extrapolation of the adage \\"By the yard is hard; by the inch it's a cinch.\\"  It uses the concept of Kaizen or continuous improvement via small steps to help people achieve goals.  Maurer's neurological explanations are consistent, though he does not back them up with references, with current neurological knowledge about how the brain adapts to circumstances and helps change behavior, i.e., by taking small Kaizen steps, a person bypasses the amygdala's fight-or-flight response, and allows the individual to gradually but surely progress towards their goals.  This book confirms what other self-help authors have advised - take that first step, however small, toward your goals, and take another one the next day, however small.  You will eventually gain momentum and achieve what you desire.
B000GG4XJM|5.0|Why pony-up for a second edition of an album released a mere six months ago?  Well, for one thing it includes a slew of bonus tracks, all worth shelling out another ten bucks for.  But the stand out is \\"How Can a Poor Man Stand Such times and Live?,\\" a 1920s blues song about the depression by \\"Blind\\" Alfred Reid that Bruce remolded the last few verses to fit the plight of New Orleans.  He posted this song on his website shortly after the original release of this album and it became a big request for fans to get their hands on as well as the centerpiece of his live shows on this tour.  And for good reason.  The song is absolutely brilliant - in sound and lyrics.  It fits perfectly amongst the folk standards on this disc but could also stand alone as a classic rock/blues single on a \\"normal\\" Springsteen disc.  You can almost hear the E Street Band pumping this one out live.  Ditto the still fresh and invigorating tracks like \\"O Mary Don't You Weep\\" that were on the original release.      There is also a DVD that includes the bonus content that was on the flip side of the original album's \\"DuelDisc,\\" plus bonus live performances from the tour this summer.  This is merely a sampling of the whale of a show that these concerts were, but as such they do a terrific job of capturing some of the energy.  Truth be told though, there were so many other great versions of Springsteen classics and other blues covers (like a phenomenal \\"Rag Mama Rag\\") performed throughout the tour that these bonus performances really make the viewer wish Columbia would have just forgone the re-release of this album and just done a live disc and/or DVD.  Any of you who were skeptical that this would be a downer of a show or some corny hoedown sorely missed out.  The show I was lucky enough to attend was a huge party and rocked as much as the average E Street show.  Springsteen put more energy into this performance than anyone could have expected, even by his high performance standards.  He knew whathis fans would want and he did not use this different type of music as an excuse to slouch.  Hopefully Columbia will release something indicative of those shows down the line.  Although, I thought his intimate shows for \\"Devils and Dust\\" were brilliant in showcasing the Boss' playing chops and strong vocals, but there has yet to be any sort of Springsteen acoustic collection (\\"D&D\\" was actually his second acoustic tour following a similar stint in the mid-90s) collection so I won't hold my breath for Columbia to release any of his more experimental music endeavors.    And finally, as many have begged for, this version does away with the \\"DuelDisc\\" format.  Many of has had no bad luck with them, but look at the reviews for the first release and you'll see that a ton of people did.  So here you get the music plus bonus tracks on a normal CD and all the DVD content of the DuelDisc plus the new live performances.  So whether you hated the DuelDisc or just want the new content or both you simply can't go wrong here.    There will be some of you who will write posts here saying things like \\"oh, they are just gouging us for money,\\" or \\"why release this again,\\" etc.  Remember, just because it's on store shelves and is out there for those so inclined to double up or feel the performances and new tracks are worth the money, does not mean you have to purchase it.  It's only a rip off to you if you buy it, otherwise its just there.  And those that choose to pick it up won't be disappointed.

B00005221M|1.0|Ok....by now anyone reading this review has read other reviews and is intimately familiar with the general plot of this film. That having been said, I will add my comments not so much with regards to the plot, but on the overall nature of what remains a stereotypical Hollywood feature. <br /> <br />Why is it that every single box-office Hollywood movie that deals with Native American subject matters has to have caucasian actors as the central figures? <br />Take any of the \\"Indian\\" films made since \\"A Man Called Horse\\" in the 70's, and you'll find some disturbing commonalities in ALL of them. <br /> <br />Let me point out a few of these disturbing facts. <br /> <br />1. The hero is always caucasian....though sometimes the actor may portray a native american character, but the the actor is caucasian none the less. I suppose in the eyes of the producers making this junk there are no native american actors good enough to play in feature films about their own history. <br /> <br />2. Real Native American culture and language is never represented as it historically existed. Hollywood changes things so as to make it more \\"sell-able\\" to the masses....who of course are not the Native American people. <br /> <br />3. The leading female role is, of course, almost always caucasian. Again....even in \\"Dances with wolves\\", a movie as relatively historically correct as any ever made, the female lead is a caucasian woman. <br /> <br />Ok....I've made my point.  <br />So, now you see why I don't like this film. Sure, it has a sort of handsome (caucasian) super hero type lead man, a somewhat attractive (caucasian) leading lady, and of course, a few natives...most of whom are not native american at all, to make for a high budget Hollywood feature but that's where the fun ends. <br />This move has nothing to do with the Mohicans who, by the way, are not now, nor ever were extinct. It has even less to do with the French - Indian wars. <br />This movie is a lame love story. The whole plot revolves around this caucasian man who was raised by Indians who falls in love with...hold your breath....a caucasian woman who ever so conveniently falls in love with him almost right away. <br />Aside from that, the movie does not flow and the music is terribly sappy and could have come from any other lame Hollywood feature...strings and all. Basically it's the same theme over and over for 2 hours. <br /> <br />While I'm at it, let me give you some examples of films that perfectly illustrate my point. <br />-Dances with Wolves (the best Hollywood movie on the subject but still very much un-native in many ways) <br />-Grey Owl (this movie should never have been made...it's another lame love story that has nothing to do with Native American history) <br />- A Man Called Horse & The sequel (Another film where a caucasian man is elevated to savior status of the oh so helpless native people...most of whom are actually played by mexican actors) <br />- Spirit Walker (here they went so far as to cast a british, and very caucasian, actor in the lead role. Ironically the role is supposed to portray a dying Indian Chief....way to go) <br /> <br />So there you have it. Even after all these years Hollywood loves it's people....and everything that comes out of it's studios is geared to \\"it's\\" people...even if it's at the expense of an entire races' culture, language and history. <br /> <br />It's a sad commentary as to how Hollywood still views the Native American people. I wonder what would happen if a Native American producer were to make a film about JFK but used only native american actors to portray the main characters? Would such a film ever see the light of day, much less garner 5 star reviews from the public? I leave the answer to this question up to you.....

But give the Wolvie his due, because he clawed the crap out of alot of members of the Brotherhood camp as he went looking for Jean, which was just totally cool. <br /> <br />The reduction and absense of certain characters sticks out like a KKK member in Harlem as there was no Nightcrawler, a virtual non-existant Rogue, an occasional Bobby, Shadowcat and Colossus sighting here and there, and brief appearances by many of the new characters introduced.  <br /> <br />On the flip side of the newbies, Beast I thought was played very well by Kelsey Grammar, and Vinny Jones as the Juggernaut was just frickin' cool. His one liner of \\"I'm the Juggernaut, b***h!\\" was just awesome, and really just personified his character to a tee. The Phoenix aspect of Jean Grey could have literally ended that film half way through if she got pissed (or bored) enough, because I have been told by comic enthusiasts that the Phoenix being, entity, whatever in the X-Men comics had destroyed entire STAR SYSTEMS in the past, much less the little thing we call Earth, so the rest of the cast kind of lucked out due to non-aggressive script writing and not following the comics completely. I'm still upset about Mystique being neutralized so early in the film, and then being turned on by Magneto, whom she had helped rescue in X-2 and followed for so long. The term'ungrateful and pompous jerk'does not even come close to covering what Magneto did to Mystique after she was turned human by the cure and he gave her the cold shoulder send off. \\"I'm sorry my dear, but you're not one of us anymore.\\" He deserved the four cure darts in his chest that he got in the end of the final fight scene via Beast for that one. <br /> <br />All in all, its an entertaining movie and worth a watch. I bought it because I was a fan of Jackman's Logan/ Wolverine character, Janssen's Jean Grey/ Phoenix, Rebecca Romjin's Mystique character, and Ian McKellen's Magneto. If you're a purist of the X-Men, you'll be pulling your hair out by the end due to how badly Ratner and his crew messed things up from a plot perspective, but the movie is actually pretty descent. Its a fun ride and a 'good' super-hero flick. <br /> <br />Not as good as it could have been, by any stretch of the imagination, but a good film none-the-less and worth watching. So watch it and make your own judgments... and check out the deleted scenes and endings to see if I was right about how they should have been left in the actual movie, where some of the stuff they left in should have been left out.

1932907009|5.0|I've been writing screenplays for 8 years now, and after being a semi-finalist in the American Film Institute's last screenwriting competition, and having a major Hollywood agent say \\"you can write kid, and I can sell you, I just need a studio caliber script,\\"  I STILL wasn't able to sell a thing.  Why?  Because I didn't really know what a studio caliber script looked like.  What exactly does Hollywood want?  It seemed that no matter how often I posed the question, all I got were blank stares and shrugged shoulders.  I was ready to give up, until I read SAVE THE CAT! And yes, I'm a seasoned reader of all things screenplay, so I've read Syd Field, Viki King, Linda Seger, Chris Vogler, and Robert McKee.  I suppose I learned something from every book, but NOTHING compared to what I learned from this one. <br /> <br />To say that SAVE THE CAT! changed my life is an understatement.  First of all, it's written by a guy who's made his living from screenwriting for the past 20 years.  A guy who's sold to Steven Spielberg.  For a million dollars.  I don't know about you, but I want to learn from someone who's actually done what I want to do.  Who's done it over and over again. <br /> <br />Blake Snyder's charming and at times \\"laugh out loud funny\\" style made the read a breeze.  In all of the years I've been doing this and reading about it, NEVER has anyone cut to the chase and explained to me why some stories sell and some don't, the way Blake has in this book.  He discusses genre, character, structure, rewriting, selling and everything in between.  All in a delightfully simple and easily understandable format.  He offers short cuts that are super effective and that save time and anguish, and sure fire ways to check your work so that you KNOW when you're finished you'll have a great story and a saleable piece of work. <br /> <br />If you're a beginner, this book will save you YEARS of trial and error.  If you're a seasoned pro, I still recommend this book because it's a great tool to help streamline the process. <br /> <br />Blake Snyder, in SAVE THE CAT!, has not only given me the confidence to move back into the world of screenwriting, which I love so much, but he's also given me the tools I need to create a studio caliber story BEFORE I put pen to paper. Chapter 1 ALONE is worth the price of admission.  It offers a simple method to help you come up with stories that fit the Hollywood paradigm AND it teaches you how to find out whether the story will sell or not.  Amazing!   <br /> <br />I'm working on a new screenplay as a result of this book, and I have no doubt that it will sell.  I've never felt that deep down in my gut before, no matter how many kudos I'd received for my scripts. <br /> <br />Buy this book, you won't know what you're missing until you do.

THE LITTLE MERMAID has become a beloved film for all of us that ever grew up with it with our loved ones. B000H5U65C|5.0|Someone who has listened to the other Mastodon albums: Leviathan, Remission, and Lifesblood over and over and over, like me, thinks they know what to expect from Mastodon. Catchy and steel-hard riffs, growling poetic vocals. And since they switched from Relapse to Reprise, gaining a much bigger production budget, you'd think the acoustics would sound different, maybe a little less fuzzy.  <br />No, this Mastodon album breaks the mold. Instead of the formula they've established, they tend to a much broader style on this album, with long melodic interludes hinted at by such previous tracks as Hearts Alive and Joseph Merrick from their Leviathan. There are several guest appearances, also a first, from the members of Mars Volta and Josh Homme of Queens of the Stone Age, which lend quite a different edge to the tracks to which they contribute. The volume is turned down a bit, but no intensity is lost, as they've moved from a hard and heavy formula to a hard and varied formula with this entry. Seldom can one pick out a repetitive riff from a song, as they seem to be writing it as they go, with incredible results. <br />This makes Mastodon's second concept album, and this is no less awe inspiring. In fact, the progression of the story is a little more clear than Leviathan, which is nice. Each song rather complements the one to either side of it, instead of giving it a \\"let's try THIS now\\" feel the previous disc had. <br />The sound is still a little fuzzy, but getting better.  <br />If you buy one CD this month, or even this year, buy this one. In fact, buy several copies for christmas presents.

She has twenty minutes to do so and what makes this film unique is that it is very time conscious.  Tom Tykwer accurately takes twenty minutes (or VERY close to) with each of Lola's attempts to save her boyfriend. <br /> <br />Lola's first attempt is to ask her father, a bank manager, for the money.  This goes horribly wrong and Lola is forced to take another route.  She makes a few attempts, and each one explores cause and affect in a strange way, showing the outcomes of everyone involved and all whom Lola interacts with until the film ends unexpectedly.   <br /> <br />The camera style here is great, fast paced and edgy, and it keeps you glued to the screen until the credits begin to roll.  I was also very impressed with the acting on the parts of the two leads, Franka Potente in particular who embraced her character with pure panic and conveyed a very convincing and realistic portrayal of a woman fighting for the life of her lover.  I haven't seen too many foreign films but after this one I'm surely going to give them a try.
B000F4PD7G|4.0|BEOWULF & GRENDEL as the title of this wonderfully atmospheric retelling of the myth is well selected: the usual name of the myth is simply BEOWULF but Sturla Gunnarsson, with the aid of screenwriter Andrew Rai Berzins,  appreciates the importance of the 'creature' Grendel and gives him equal billing.  Not all audiences will agree with the decision to make Grendel 'humanized' (he was actually a giant troll monster in the original tale), but the manner in which this story is related makes this concept of Grendel as a being with memory and feelings more pertinent to contemporary audiences.<br /><br />King Hrothgar (Stellan Skarsgrd) once killed a troll whose son Grendel (Ingvar Eggert Sigursson) survived and has been vengefully killing the Danish court of the king to the point that the king has lost all power.  A monk, Brendan the Celt (Eddie Marsan), comes to Denmark (the time is 400 AD) to spread Christianity, baptize the population and pray for the protection of the people form Grendel. King Hrothgar calls upon a Hero in the form of Beowulf (Gerard Butler) who travels the seas, only to be shipwrecked and come ashore with his few men to aid the decimated kingdom and king.  Once in Denmark, Beowulf strategizes his attack on Grendel, the mighty son of the original troll, survives the many attacks that leave many dead and torn limb from limb, and finally is responsible for ridding the land of Grendel.  Along the way Beowulf is aided by a witch Selma (Sarah Polley) who defends Grendel's philosophy: we later discover that she bore a child by Grendel.  After many chases and conflicts Beowulf is responsible for Grendel's death and the kingdom rejoices while Beowulf is conflicted by the fact that he has killed a troll with a heart and soul.  There are many metaphors between Christianity and mythology that are beautifully explored by the story as told here.<br /><br />Filmed in Iceland and Canada the mythic mood of the tale is well served by cinematographer Jan Kiesser and the musical score by Hilmar &Ouml;rn Hilmarsson.  One is reminded of the paintings of Odd Nerdrum.  The stormy darkness of the entire film fits the story well and the actors, especially the always superb and charismatic Gerard Butler, make their characters as credible as myth allows.  The many accents of the actors make understanding the lines a problem and even though the dialogue is in English, subtitles would have greatly helped understanding the storyline as it unfolds.<br /><br />Many people will object to the character of Grendel as extracted here from the original myth, but for this observer the way in which we are allowed to understand the motivation of this rather pitiful beast makes the story far more poignant.  The added features on the DVD include  Gerard Butler discussing his role and his decision to accept the Beowulf persona.  And equally as interesting is a behind the scenes track that demonstrates the difficulties in filming a story in rugged terrain.  In all this is a visually stunning, emotionally moving film well worth the attention of the audience.  Grady Harp, October 06er and the musical score by Hilmar rn Hilmarsson. 0618680004|4.0|If God does not exist, it would be a cruel irony that mankind has evolved to the point where it can comprehend its own aimless existance-- only able to invent a moral purpose of its own, given none conferred on it externally.  But if God does exist-- how does He *know* He's God?  Maybe He just *thinks* He's God-- a mere megalomaniacal inmate of some cosmic asylum?  Even if the omniscient truly knows all there is to know-- such a one still cannot rule out the possibility that there is something outside its ability to perceive and therefore potentially subject to an even greater external moral purpose (however mysterious).  What could possibly be more utterly fantastic, more completely *unbelievable* than an invisible, mysterious super-being?  Is one to be held accountable to such patently unbelievable entities?     No, ALL are left to invent their moral purpose, Gods and mankind alike, as the alternative is to abdicate the responsibility for it in deferring to a phantom superior.  A daunting responsibility no doubt, considerably more difficult to think through, than is simply accepting someone else's conveniently packaged and marketed solution.      Dawkins does a pretty good job of covering the bases. I have two disagreements with him-- first, is when he suggests that God could prove his existance if he so chose by putting in an appearance. My disagreement with that is that there is nothing that God could actually do that could prove that he's actually God, either to us or himself. For us, no matter what magical prestidigitation might ensue, a simpler explanation would be an alien with a holographic projector of some kind, or some other advanced technology ala Arthur C. For God, he cannot prove a being that oversees even him does not exist, and therefore he may not in fact be the ultimate uberbeing. Even God cannot prove for certain that he is not a brain in a vat, or logical equivalent.  Therefore, even God cannot insure he has the moral authority to rule over us--at best, just the power.  And thus, the best reason to disbelieve in God is not in even covered in Dawkins' book, and that is that a coherent definition is lacking.    Second, Dawkins could do a better job of addressing those outside the atheist choir. Unfortunately, right off the bat, Chapter 2 starts with a laundry list diatribe that essentially says \\"I don't like the Christian God because [he sucks].\\" And then refers to the \\"insipidly opposite\\" Jesus. Few Christians will make it past those two paragraphs, I suspect, and it is therefore unfortunate they occur so early in the book, if at all. While I tend to agree with his characterization, it makes a piss poor sales presentation. He need not water down his points, just relate them in a somewhat less inflammatory manner, which in fact he does pretty well for most of the rest of the book.    The remainder of the book thus was somewhat a letdown once realizing that few Christians will actually make it that far, and they are the ones who really need to \\"get\\" the points. I enjoyed his points, but for the most part already agree with them-- I'm not someone he needs to convince. Chapter 5, \\"The Roots of Religion\\" had some particularly interesting ideas regarding religion as a by-product of something else, though it's clear further thought needs to be done in this area. Chapter 6, \\"Roots of Morality\\" should be required reading in school.
0141301120|4.0|This was a really odd book. By the end of the first book, Charlie, his grandparents, his parents, and Mr Wonka are all in a glass elevator, shooting into the sky. From here, they go to outer space where a space hotel is opening and some American astronauts find them and assume they are enemy aliens. They, along with the infantile and incredibly stupid president of the United States contemplate blowing up the glass elevator and all inside to protect the soon-to-be occupied space hotel. With Wonka's gadgets, they manage to board the hotel, find real and very dangerous aliens, escape, and save the foolish Americans from being gobbled up...for the most part. When they return to the factory, Wonka offers a volatile youth potion to his grandparents, but only the selfish Josephina gets any...and all of it. She disappears as she becomes uninvented, Charlie and Wonka find her in the mysterious place where negatives live, and that's pretty much it. A series of non-sequitors, but funny nonetheless.

0618551050|5.0|What is really cool about this book is its survey of theories of physics that have been considered since the renaissance to the present. It describes both successful theories and unsuccessful ones. Its discussion of unsuccessful attempts is very insightful, and many of the theories discussed I have never heard of before. Its survey of string theory at a lay-person level is the most detailed yet readable I have seen anywhere. I also very much like the insights into the mindset of how successive generations of physicists worked. I still have about a hundred pages left to read -- the review whim comes rarely to me, so I striking while its still hot -- but at this point this book get a definite thumbs up.

0618680004|1.0|Not just a disappointment, the book simply not very good.    Dawson claims his intent is to persuade to atheism those who are uncomfortable with their own religious belief.  Yet his mocking, sneering condescension to and contempt for religious believers will put off many whom he might otherwise have influenced.  He is oblivious to the intensity of religious experience.  Religious belief generally correlates negatively with intelligence, but many believers are of course extraordinarily intelligent. While that doesn't count for or against their belief, Dawkins does not do well to treat believers as fools.  He should reread (I hope it's re-) William James' The Varieties of Religious Experience; doing so might add depth and humanity to his view of believers.     Dawkins seems curiously unfamiliar with contemporary philosophical thought, perhaps because it tends to undercut his desire to subject religion to \\"scientific\\" analysis.  He isn't very good at the history of philosophy either.  I am neither believer, unbeliever, nor agnostic.  I can't make enough sense out of the use of \\"god\\" to know what might count for or against the correctness of its use to denote anything.  Dawson doesn't understand this position, although it isn't original with me and requires little philosophical sophistication to grasp.  By the way, Anselm's ontological argument is by its own terms valid, but does not prove the existence of \\"god\\" as Dawkins uses the term.     Dawkins takes as his paradigm the argument between creationists and evolutionists.  Creationism is both wrong and silly.  But Dawkins will not dent those who previously resisted his arguments.  It is easy to mock the vagaries and inconsistencies of religious conservatives.  Fundamenatalists are in fact powerful forces for ignorance, irrationalism, and intolerance.  For that very reason, if H.L. Mencken couldn't finish them off, Dawkins is unlikely to.    Dawkins wanders from his \\"delusion\\" theme when he speaks of the damage wroughtby organized religion.  Evil done in the name of god is obviously irrelevant as to whether god exists.  Dawkins justifiably points to awful historical effects of belief, including 9/11.  He does, however, ignore the political component of many, if not most, \\"religious\\" conflicts such as the Thirty Years war and the Troubles in Northern Ireland.  Dawkins speeds past secular outrages such as Russia under Stalin, China under Mao, Rwanda, Cambodia, American lynchings of blacks, the Armenian genocide, King Leopold in the Congo, the near extinction of Native Americans.  Religion is not necessary to human vileness.

B000HCO840|4.0|With Bryan Singer and his writing team moving on to the Superman franchise, Marvel and Fox scrambled to get the third, and for now final, X-Men film out as quick as possible, with director Brett Ratner getting to direct the installment.  Now make no mistake, Ratner is a hack director at best, and his best talents are displayed in the many action scenes throughout the film, many of which are nicely done.  The story picks up a while after X2, with Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) and Storm (Halle Berry) training a young group of mutants including Iceman (Shawn Ashmore), Rogue (Anna Paquin), Shadowcat (Ellen Paige), and Colossus (Daniel Cudmore) while Cyclops (James Marsden) is still mourning the death of Jean (Famke Janssen).  In the meantime, a cure for mutants is announced, prompting Magneto (Ian McKellen) to organize his Brotherhood as Jean returns from the dead to make short work of Professor Xavier (Patrick Stewart) and anyone else in her way.  For the most part, X-Men: The Last Stand is solid enough to stand out on it's own, but it really misses the touch that Singer and his crew had on the characters.  The dark tone is still here, but the characterization injected in the previous two films gets the second tier treatment here.  Many characters, mainly Cyclops and Rogue, are almost completely ignored to make way for new characters like Beast (Kelsey Grammer, perfectly cast) and Angel (Ben Foster, who plays a much lesser role than you would think), while new villains are introduced including Juggernaut (Vinnie Jones, yes, Vinnie Jones in a fake looking muscle suit and all) and Multiple Man (Eric Dane), while Mystique (Rebecca Romijn) and Pyro (Aaron Stanford) get a backseat.  There's loads of in-references that longtime X-fans will get (the Days of Futures Past nod is a nice touch, and Stan Lee and Chris Claremont make cameos), but to believe that this is the last X-Men film is just silly.  It could have been better (and longer, the film is over way too quick), but it could have been a lot worse too, so maybe we should count our blessings.ld have been a lot worse too, so maybe we should count our blessings.

0060934913|5.0|Anthony Bourdain is a person I would be friends with if I knew him.  He's cynical, he's blunt and he loves food.   <br /> <br />\\"Kitchen Confidential\\" is a collection of tales from Chef Bourdain's past-- these stories are all very memorable.  As many other reviewers have stated, the book is funny and eye-opening.  But what I also want to add is that Bourdain is a very good writer.  He knows how to tell a story that is fast-moving, interesting, funny and worthwhile.  The bulk of the book takes place in the New York City restaurant scene, which is a universe unto itself.  Bourdain's personal experiences through this maze of liars, drugs, cheats and the mafia are fascinating.  When I was finished, I was sad that the stories ended.  I have since vowed to go to Bourdain's downtown bistro Les Halles to experience this guy's menu.  But \\"Kitchen Confidential\\" is first and foremost about the insane people that make the food.  I highly recommend this book.

B0009I7NNA|4.0|Since I bought this album a year ago I've moved onto harder and heavier bands, like Slayer and Cradle of Filth, and even some older ones too, like Iron Maiden and Ozzy. Avenged Sevenfold has evolved into something that fits right in the middle of all of that. They even seem to have an anti-war feeling in two of the songs, despite the fact that they claim to not be a political band at all.<br /><br />Many fans of Waking the Fallen and Sounding the Seventh Trumpet will be disappointed over the fact that M. Shadows chose to tone down his level of screaming. They may also be upset over the feeling that the band's music isn't exactly as heavy as their prior two albums. Despite this, the band has managed a very solid album, especially for one that spans over a full 78 minutes.<br /><br />The disc takes right off with the band's brutal second single, Beast and the Harolt and continues right through to the album's first single, Bat Country. The song was rated the 2nd best song of the year by Fuse for 2005 and is extremely overplayed on the radio, but that doesn't mean it's not a wild ride. In fact it's really quite insane and the music video just adds enough sex and comedy to make it that much better. Next is Trashed and Scattered, which is very vulgar yet keeps turning from heavy to interestingly catchy. Seize the Day is up next and what a song it is! I personally like this song more than the amazing ballad of Warmness on the Soul from their first album and the music video for it is nothing short of brilliant. Sidewinder kicks it off slowly but turns very catchy after a good few minutes of listening when the bongos are added. The Wicked End is a dark and awesome tale of apocalypse by demons, as, I'd assume, prophecized in the Book of Revelations. Strength of the World has a very powerful story behind it, where a man's family is shot before him and he seeks revenge for their deaths. Betrayed is a tribute to Dimebag Darrel of Pantera who was shot and killed on-stage by a crazed fan. The title to the track itself is a reference to both sides, I feel, as the fan probably felt betrayed that Darrel had moved onto a new band or Darrel for having a fan kill him. M.I.A. ends the album with an 8 minute war story of a man in Iraq who is forced to kill and forced to see death around him and live in fear and then, in the aftermath, he must live with guilt and rejection from others.<br /><br />Overall the album proved to be a true masterpiece however it detracts from the feeling of A7X's previous efforts. It also strays from the death metal/metalcore style and leans more towards nu-metal. But that also means, at the same time, others may begin to have a bit more appreciation for the music (my parents, who aren't very fond of metal at all anymore, loved it).<br /><br />--4/5 Stars--zed fan. The title to the track itself is a reference to both sides, I feel, as the fan probably felt betrayed that Darrel had moved onto a new band or Darrel for having a fan kill him. M.I.A. ends the album with an 8 minute war story of a man in Iraq who is forced to kill and forced to see death around him and live in fear and then, in the aftermath, he must live with guilt and rejection from others.<br /><br />Overall the album proved to be a true masterpiece however it detracts from the feeling of A7X's previous efforts. 0452257743|5.0|\\"The Long Walk\\" is my favorite novella in this series.  Never in so few pages can any author amaze me like King can.  The way he writes is so matter-of-fact in this story. <br /> <br />I bought the book when I was in Jr. High, but things were much different then. 0618551050|5.0|I really enjoyed reading this book.  I've been fascinated with theoretical physics for a long time, but lately the things I've read have made me suspect that physics (or at least particle physics) might have lost its way.  This is exactly the thesis of Smolin's book; string theory, the dominant theory in particle physics, is according to Smolin  a very complex theory that has so many forms that it can be adapted to almost any data, and therefore isn't falsifiable, can't generate testable predictions, and thus isn't really science.  Smolin spends a lot of time setting the stage for the emergence of string theory as the currently dominant paradigm for particle physics despite having essentially no experimental support.  He gives a good description of string theory's initial appeal as well as its slow evolution (devolution?) into a \\"theory of anything\\" that seems to be unable to be tested as normal scientific theories are supposed to be.  I enjoyed having the gaps in my knowledge filled in in this way, albeit by an admittedly biased source. <br /> <br />Then Smolin gives an all-too-brief description of some experimental results which challenge the dominant paradigm (or ones that will happen in the next few years that look like they might challenge it), as well as some theoretical alternatives to string theory.  The impression one gets is that the alternative theories are fascinating but not nearly as thoroughly worked out as string theory, which is hardly surprising given the far fewer number of people who work on them.  To his credit, Smolin doesn't suggest that any of the other theories are the \\"right\\" theory that will \\"fix\\" string theory's errors; he believes instead that there is something fundamentally missing in our understanding of space, time, and the quantum that is adversely affecting all current theories.  I found this section of the book really intriguing, as nearly all of the theories and experimental results in this section were new to me. <br /> <br />However, the best part of the book is the last, where Smolin gives a somewhat angry description of academic politics and the need for a recognition that theoretical physics (and science in general) needs not just people with good technical skills (the \\"craftspeople\\") but also people whose expertise is in dreaming up radically new theories (the \\"seers\\").  He argues that academic institutions (especially in the US) are set up to exclusively favor craftspeople over seers, leading to a dead end when science needs seers to create a revolution.  My own (fairly extensive) experience in the scientific community tends to support this view, but with a major caveat that Smolin mentions but doesn't spend much time on: it's easy to distinguish who are the good craftspeople, but it's pretty hard to distinguish the true \\"seers\\" from just cranks.  Smolin's answer (that other seers can tell who the real seers are) is not really that satisfying, because if all of them are cranks, who cares what they think of each other? <br /> <br />Nevertheless, I think that the distinction between seers and craftspeople is a fundamental one, and this book deserves a lot of credit for introducing these concepts into the scientific dialogue.  In this sense, the book is reminiscent of Kuhn's _The Structure of Scientific Revolutions_, but much less dry. <br /> <br />Since I'm not a physicist, I can't evaluate whether Smolin's statements about physics are fair or not.  What would be interesting is to see a non-hostile, non-ad-hominem, reasoned rebuttal to this book by someone in the string theory community who knows how to write (Brian Greene, here's your next project!).  Regardless, I think anyone interested in physics and in science will find lots to think about in this book.

B000GY729M|4.0|On The Killers' epic sophomore disc Flowers and Co. have jettisoned the New Wave stomp of \\"Hot Fuss\\" and replaced it with expansive hook-filled nostalgia. The album opens powerfully (much like the adrenaline kick of \\"Fuss\\" opener \\"Jenny Was A Friend Of Mine\\"), the signature propulsive drums and keyboards raising the curtains and unveiling cinematic vignettes of Midwestern Americana. \\"I've never really known anybody to die before,\\" Flowers croons, painting a vivid picture of a grandmother's wake.  <br /> <br />The title track is followed by \\"Enterlude,\\" a short thematic primer whose melody is later reprised in the excellent album closer \\"Exitlude.\\" \\"We hope you enjoy your stay, it's good to have you with us, even if it's just for the day,\\" Flowers sings, as if the listener is a drifter passing through an old western town. This being a concept album (supposedly), it makes sense to frame the songs in the context of a brief excursion into \\"Sam's Town.\\" In fact, the album works best when viewed in this way. As demonstrated on \\"Hot Fuss\\" the Killers are good at inhabiting a musical niche. \\"Fuss\\" itself was a concept album of sorts, the '04 Killers were a bunch of eyeliner wearing, androgynous disco-dwellers with an affinity for synthesizers. The new Killers have taken a fancy to the mythic American West, and instead of cribbing from Bowie they've grown scruffy beards and are now taking lessons from Springsteen. He is, after all, the Boss.  <br /> <br />In addition to the title track and single \\"When You Were Young,\\" highlights include the bouncy \\"For Reason's Unknown,\\" the earnest \\"Read My Mind,\\" and the Queen inspired \\"Why Do I Keep Counting?\\"  <br /> <br />Only time will tell if \\"Sam's Town\\" will be the mass success that it's predecessor was. I for one am relieved this disc is as good as it is. After hearing \\"Hot Fuss\\" for the first time, The Killers were one of my favorite bands. It's good to report that after hearing \\"Sam's Town\\" they will remain that way.

B00009W0U4|5.0|Other than the slightly confusing chronology of the very last scenes (made up for by an overwhelming and very sudden ending), this is one of the most gorgeous and brutal films I have ever seen. The cast is flawless, which actually aids in the discomfort factor...when Monica Bellucci's character is raped, it isn't just the ultra-raw, minimal camera style (the camera stays completely stationary) that causes you to flinch-it's the moans and screams that she makes during the entire ordeal. You actually feel like you're watching a woman get brutally assaulted...and even with all that going on, the director manages to add another disturbing elemant to the shot toward the end. While a lot of \\"disturbing-film-list\\" movies can be pointless and gratuitous, the violence here is not only realistic and essential to the storytelling, but actually underscores the even more disturbing \\"can't turn back time/no matter how bad it is it can get MUCH worse\\" message contained in the characters' actions and futile attempts at \\"justice\\". Not for the faint of heart, but if you love the artistic aspect of movie-making, this is an amazingly crafted film that almost makes you feel as if you're being slapped in the face while watching.

B000E6UWE4|5.0|Gardens of the Moon is like few fantasy books you'll ever read.  The author drops you into a world at the beginning, without any explanation, and lets you slowly absorb the personalities and locals he has created.  Since this is the first of a 10 volume series, Erickson is in no hurry to push the push the plot along, but by the end, you can't wait for the sequel.  As in any really good book, the author uses seemingly unimportant acts to have important consequences later in the novel.  The world that Erickson has created can be dark and gritty.  The characters can be either good or bad, but sometimes making a value judgement is not easy. All in all, a really good piece of fantasy writing.

038572179X|5.0|This is one of the finest 3 books I have read in the last 10 years. The others being \\"As Meat Loves Salt\\" by Maria McCann and \\"Ghost Road\\" by Pat Barker.    Ian McEwan's writing is virtually flawless. His brilliant descriptions and phrasing makes reading effortless and engaging. His character development is of the highest level, comparable to Austen. His sense of history and the effects of history on the individual's life trajectory is superb, much like Tolstoy's War and Peace.  His acute ear for the signs of classism and its destructive forces compares to Dickens and Hugo. His description of the horrors of war were both matter of fact and moving, much like that of Pat Barker's World War I trilogy.    Rather than discuss the plot, which has been discussed numerous times in many of the posted reviews, I would prefer to discuss the themes that McEwan explores with great insight.    The first theme that I found engaging was that of maturity of emotion and development of personal character/courage, as exemplified in the character of Briony. What is it within us that matures? Briony finds that with time her emotions mature, allowing her first to engage as a nurse probationer in an army hospital and then to engage her sister Cecelia and Cecelia's lover, Robbie, both of whom she had wronged many years before. Maturity means forsight into the consequences of our decisions and actions and this force is hopefully paired with character which is the willingness to accept responsibility for those decisions and actions when they go astray. Thus experience that results in increased control of emotion, forthought, and assuming responsibility when wrong are those forces that bring about a healthy maturity with corresponding character development. McEwan develops this theme beautifully, even to the final passages of the book where the elderly Briony reflects on this process that she underwent so many years before.    The second theme I found engaging was the effects of classism, a social structure that acts as a barrier but can be overcome by those with courage and compassion. Cecelia and Robbie's love was first impeded by class until a happy accident allows Cecelia to understand the level of passion that Robbie secretly holds for her. In this regard McEwan explores a theme often explored by E. M. Forrester. Forrester in \\"Maurice\\", like McEwan in \\"Atonement\\",reveals that passion can move us beyond social definitions and toward a more authentic life. When Robbie accidently sends the obscene note to Cecelia, its authenticity breaks every barrier and releases them to experience pent up and held back affections and passions. The note, with its direct crude language, hits Cecelia almost like Zen enlightenment, revealing to her all that she had felt but hidden under a veneer of social control.    The third theme I found engaging was that of the creative impulse and the maturation of that force. Movement toward the state of artistic control means curtailing and directing the imagination, rather than allowing it to run wild. Briony learns this lesson and many are punished as a result.    The fourth theme of the book relates to the nature of atonement itself. Atonement has both internal and external manifestations, depending on whether the transgression has damaged the self or others or both. Briony makes both an internal atonement as she persues life as a nurse, treating the horribly wounded soldiers. But she also makes an external atonement as she attempts to recify the damage she has done.    Very few works of art are as profound, moving, and sublime as this novel.    The final aspect of the book I found engaging was McEwan's incredible ability to produce a tangible 'place' in the mind of the reader. The English country house with its Triton fountain; the sandy beaches of Dunkirk filled with thousands of wounded English soldiers; the army hospital fully of the maimed and dying; all come absolutely alive under the careful writing style of McEwan.
0060763280|1.0|To really get the most of this book, I would just use it when I'm down or not feeling confident.  This book is a real motivation booster.  But it should just be that.  The book basically consists of 3 parts.  The first part is about the \\"Millionaire Blueprint\\".  That is, what is limiting you may be a result of your past.  But, by becoming AWARE of this part of the past and UNDERSTANDing how it is limiting you and by being willing to DISSOCIATE from it and then DECLARING the change, you can develop this \\"Millionaire Blueprint\\".  Bascially, to make a long story short, millionaires walk the talk so take action.  The second part of the book, which makes up the bulk of the book, consists of traits of millionaires.  Whether it's true or not, we don't really know.  The author doesn't give any evidence that millionaires possess any of these traits.  There is nothing to support his claims even though he gives some compelling arguments.  The traits are questionable but reasonable. You have to wonder about this.  I have yet to know someone that became rich from network marketing.  Also, network marketing companies love books like these because they inspire their workers to work harder and at the same time, help the author sell more books so this works out for everybody except for the poor suckers that buy into this (again, inspiration should be checked with reality).  In case you don't know, Amway's backing of Kiyosaki's Rich Dad book is what made it into a best-seller.  Again, I think this book is very inspirational and if that is what you want, that is what you are going to get.  But it does not tell you specifically how to get rich (no such book) and you should not look for it to help you in any other way but to inspire you.  It's better to read books by reputable authors to get a feel of what you really need to do to get rich.  Better yet, read autobiographies or biographies of successful people.  I read all of these and from them, I learned that it's not enough to take action as this book suggests.  If you take action and it's totally the wrong action, that won't get you any closer to being rich.  Action must be guided by a balance of reality and calculated risk.  Blindly diving into something will probably cost you more than doing nothing.  Drive that is powered by emotion only will not do the job.  Anyway, it's hard to take this book seriously when I see names like Kiyosaki and Robert Allen.  Good luck.what made it into a best-seller. 0440237688|5.0|The Giver, by Lois Lowry, is an excellent work of literature. It presents a stunning example of a futuristic, dystopian society where all facets of life are controlled by various rules and regulations in an easily readable format. Jonas, the novel's protagonist, is chosen by the council to become the successor to the Giver, a man whose job is to mentally store the collective memories of society. The book focuses on situations such as a society without individuality, the importance of choice, and how people react to finding out that the accepted truths of their world were at one point not the case. Ms. Lowry uses chilling imagery, such as the lack of color, the inability of most people to love, and the unemotional \\"release\\" of those who don't fit into the government's carefully laid out plans for a perfect society to establish a mood that, while somewhat bleak, is not entirely without hope. The story picks up as it progresses, shifting to a more tense, but still equally atmospheric, form. This tension is skillfully maintained until the story's conclusion. I would heartily recommend this story to all those who enjoy fictional works that focus on either individualism vs. society or potential visions of the future. <br /> <br />- Benton Wilson (a member of the Mythology and Folklore VHS class)

It has many great actors in the show, especially Chandra Wilson. She is a powerful actress.  The cast is diverse and the show keeps you wanting more. B000GY729M|5.0|There are many negative reviews of this album and I'm quite sure it's because some people like their melodies easy, catchy and bordering on Indie and bubblegum crap. I loved Hot Fuss and when I listened to this album the first time it really turned me off. A day later, I listened to it and the songs felt different to me. A few hours later, I hit \\"Sam's Town,\\" \\"When You Were Young,\\" \\"Bones\\" and \\"This River is Wild\\" and wondered why I disliked the album. <br /> <br />This is completely and utterly NOT Hot Fuss Redux. This is a different album built on a similar philosophy of song writing, but the band seems less interested in being pigeon-holed and more interested in being varied. If you liked Mr. Brightside, Somebody Told Me and Midnight Show but thought the rest of Hot Fuss was sub-par, you won't like this disc much, I don't think. It's got a lot stronger instrumentation, pounding basslines and overall great production value. <br /> <br />And for anyone who complains about any band, anywhere being \\"all in the studio,\\" grow up, would you please? That's not a critique of an album, that's a complaint that should be lodged against the entire music industry. The Killers pride themselves on a new take of using synthesizors, of course they rely on a studio heavily. Listen to the VH1 acoustic sessions or the Live at the Wireless bootleg and you will hear the merit of the Killers' musical capacity. That's like complaining that someone's voice doesn't sound like it's got a vibraphone in person, and here's the reason why: it's a studio invention. <br /> <br />The Killers, contrary to what most would like to think about modern music, do have the ability to write well. All of the songs, save perhaps Uncle Johnny which is vaguely boring, have strong writing. The strongest among all the bands in the world? I wouldn't know, I've certainly not listened to all the music in the world. But it's very solid, backed up by a band that knows how to play and play well. <br /> <br />This is avery solid album and the term \\"Sophomore Slump\\" shouldn't be used in the same sentence with it.

B000FTWB7G|4.0|It's been a damn long wait, but Evanescence have returned to the scene after being M.I.A. for the past two years. Lots has happened to inspire and fuel the material on the band's highly anticipated third disc. For starters, there's the obvious gap left by co-founder Ben Moody, who bailed-out on the band in 2003, at the height of the band's popularity. There's his replacement, ex-Cold guitarist Terry Balsamo. And personal turmoil for frontlady Amy Lee, from lawsuits to a break-up with Seether frontman Shaun Morgan (who is tastelessly put in the hot-seat on \\"Call Me When You're Sober\\"). It's fair to say that the band had a lot to prove going into this record.<br /><br />Sounds like: \\"Fallen\\" redux.<br /><br />The Good:<br />- Evanescence have finally put something new out.<br />- The songs are darker, more ambitious and less poppy.<br />- Balsamo is a better guitarist than Moody.<br /><br />The Bad:<br />- For all the waiting, it's not nearly as awesome as it should be .<br />- The album seems to be a carbon-copy of \\"Fallen\\" at times. For example, \\"Sweet Sacrifice\\" is to \\"Going Under\\" as \\"Call Me When You're Sober\\" is to \\"Bring Me To Life.\\"<br />- Balsamo doesn't bring the goods here like he did in his Cold days.<br /><br />Hits: \\"Weight Of The World,\\" \\"Good Enough\\" and \\"Lacrymosa.\\"<br /><br />Misses: \\"Call Me When You're Sober,\\" a horribly tacky Kelly Clarkson-esque song that didn't need to be written.<br /><br />Future: \\"The Open Door\\" is standard fare for Evanescence. I predict it will be a huge hit, and like it's predecessor, will be imprinted into our memory, thanks to excessive abuse on the radio.<br /><br />Personally: I like this album quite a bit for now, but I feel that it won't have as much shelf life as \\"Fallen.\\" It's good, but it's really more of the same. A lot of what I expected the band to come out with wasn't delivered.<br /><br />Best Listened To When: You're Bored With \\"Fallen.\\"

B000HIVO64|4.0|I felt OK writing a review on release day because Beck was leaking videos and other new tracks on his myspace page for a month or two before. Cool song and by far the best video on the DVD.  It is as if Stanley Kubrick directed the video laced to early 80s underground beats.  One person commented that Beck resembles Willy Wonka a bit here.    \\"We Dance Alone\\" - I just added this one because it caught on with me after a while.  This is probably a song that showcases Beck's eclecticism more than any other, many different things going on here.    \\"No complaints\\" - Very catchy; one of the most stripped down tracks on the album, perfect for the MP3 player, walking outside.  Great lyrics.    \\"The Information\\" - The title track has a hard bass beat and is solid overall.    The last song is a montage of a couple different tracks, focusing on change.   This album was marketed different from the others; Beck is telling us the music is changing.  Example: I went out and bought it rather than downloading this . . . Why?    Partly because of the DVD that comes with the album, partly the releases on myspace.  Brilliant marketing focusing more on the album as a package.  And I'm still split on rating it vs. Guero.  Even though there were some tracks I could do without, (e.g. - Motorcade) when rating this album you have to keep in mind that Beck made a video for every song.  Has anyone done that before???  And then NOT charge us a lot for it?  At well under $15 here, this is a bargain for an album with 15 tracks and 15 videos on DVD.    I could go on about the stickers, but I won't.  Beck has attempted something different and I liked it, hope you do too.  Let's watch if the rest of the music industry follows suit.
B000FTWB7G|5.0|Evanescence has promised us a bigger, better album, and this album it shows. They've clearly pushed all of their limits and the used all the talents they could. Amy used her powerful voice much more than on Fallen. The vocal was just utterly amazing and gave the album sort of a dream-like, gothic-powerful, carefree and windy feeling. The lyrics weren't as complicated as the last one but it worked well and, as others say, gets their messages across. And they came out with an album not like any other albums out there, and clearly not like Fallen, just as they've said in previews. <br />The album does take a little time to get fully use to. Simply because we aren't adapted at hearing different things. Fallen was a success simply because it was something new and different, and a breath of fresh air from other music. And we were fascinated at this \\"new genre\\" (of course there are other albums of this genre, they are just not very well known). So now after three years adapting into Fallen, they come out with something else and yes, coming out of Fallen and adapt into this new album- The Open Door, takes a bit of time to get use to. But it still sounds every bit like Evanescence, and that's the most important thing. When I heard this album, my first reaction was the relief that it still sounds very much like them, second reaction was the amazing quality of Amy's vocal and the complications of the sound/background-music mixing.   <br />The thing is, you REALLY have to keep an open mind and give it a bit more chance before throwing the \\"it's so TERRIBLE\\" out there. I mean, what do you expect? They are only human, are you expecting they come out SO incredible that it'll terminate all the other albums that ever existed on earth? You already know that they aren't coming out with another Fallen, as Amy repetitively said that it's gonna be a surprise and that it's totally different from Fallen. You may like Fallen better but I can bet that that's because of the first-initial bias, if they came out with this album first and then Fallen, I bet there are gonna be numerous complains about how they became more mainstream, how they became more pop-sounding, how they've \\"fallen\\" blah blah blah. Of course, critics will always be critics. But just remember that what is \\"better\\" isn't a statement, it's an opinion of acceptation. In fact, I have friends who like Evanescence but haven't heard all of Fallen (basically those people who aren't as adapted into Fallen) have said that they liked this album very much and that it sounded just like them (in fact, they say that they couldn't distinguish The Open Door from Fallen) <br />However, for myself, there are a few minor things about the album that I find disappointing: Call Me When You're Sober as the first single- I totally get that this is probably the most stand-out song (but then again, that could also be because of the first-initial bias of things, if they came out another song as their fist single things would most likely be different who knows), but if you look at their lyrics from the chorus: \\"don't cry to me, if you love me, you would be here with me, you love me, confine me, make up your mind!\\", if you haven't heard their song and didn't know it was an Evanescence song, would you believe it was an Evanescence song? The lyrics from the chorus have bugged me a little, and whenever I hear it I always go (.......) because it sounded more like one of those complaining lyrics like Avril Lavigne's  than their soul-bearing, poetic lyrics. I've had no problem with any other of their lyrics on any other songs, just this one. Could be because it's their first single, but the first time I heard it I got the (..........) feeling (especially at the end when she sings: \\"don't lie to me, just get your things, I've made up your mind\\"). But the first time I heard their other songs I had no problem whatsoever with their lyrics. I didn't like the music video either, it was too overdone and the only good about it was the scenery and costume. The story simply isn't moving, at least not as moving as their previous music videos. And also I tend to like more complex lyrics, which they had more on Fallen, so that I find a tiny bit disappointing, but just a tiny bit, all the lyrics does get their messages across very well so I'm not complaining.  <br />The best thing about this album is that it's very different than anything I've heard before. It's darker, more carefree, better vocal, and it wrote about more variety of things than just plain feeling. That I like. This album also clearly showed that they are growing and that they aren't afraid to try new things. Also, the story of this album did follow up to Fallen, for they build up on top one another in their similarity. For example in WOTW she sings \\"I won't be held down by who I use to be, she's nothing to me\\" kind of follow up on Everybody's Fool. And another quite clear example is Like You follow up to Hello in which she talks more about her pain of losing her sister but this time she even formed the thought of suicide in order to join her sister(wonder if she's willing to sing this one on their concerts). Even Good Enough (which btw, isn't really as \\"happy\\" as one would think, it's more of a yearning song) kind of followed up to My Immortal when she sings \\"so take care of what you ask of me, `cause I can't say no\\" <br />Another good thing is that the album is 10 minutes longer YAY! `cause I was worrying that they are gonna put in one of those ridiculous interludes to waste the time and space. Thank god they did not waste anything- instead of giving us a break in the middle with slow songs like on Fallen. It was rocking through almost the entire album and then ends with a slow ballet, I really like that.  <br />Overall, this album definitely does not mark their fall or their \\"evanescence\\" anytime soon. It is quite an extraordinary album and well worth for fans to own.  <br />

B000GY729M|5.0|This second album finds the Killers departing the sound that made them famous on Hot Fuss and developing a \\"concept\\" album that is anything but typical.  The lead singer Brandon Flowers told MTV that this would be \\"the best album in the past 20 years\\".  Well...I don't know about that but it definitely is the freshest album that has come out in the past 20 years.  The album sounds like country western music that has been put in a synth meat grinder and added with some U2ish cord styles, all in the layout of the Beatle's Sgt. Pepper.  The album is a vast depature from the mood of \\"Hot Fuss\\"...this album is more complete, more optomistic, and maybe even more flamboyant.<br /><br />The album begins with one of the most charged up songs I've heard in years called \\"Sam's Town\\".  With Flowers screaming \\"why do you waste my time? Is the answer to the question on your mind\\".  The song might be the best on the entire album.  It is certainly my favorite.  If you ever need to psych yourself up...just put this beauty on a turn up the volume!<br /><br />Next is \\"Enterlude\\" which welcomes you to the album and bids that its \\"good to have you with us even if its just for the day\\" behind a few catchy keyboard cords.<br /><br />\\"When you were young\\" is the first single off the album and probably one of my least favorite songs however it is still great...another charged up chord style rock song.  Very fast paced and edgy.<br /><br />\\"Bling\\" is a very kind of whimsicle song that really grows on you after a few listens.  The song builds into a very catchy mix of all kinds of synth sounds behind powerful bass line.<br /><br />\\"For reasons Unknown\\" is a great kind of 80's throw away song that sounds like it was made in the middle of the desert.  Really neat song.<br /><br />\\"Read my mind\\" probably the most catchy songs on the album and one of my favorites...sounds very 80s movie soundtrack-ish.  A slower song with an aluring simple guitar riff that repeats with the corus...very chordal.  Great song and sure to be another single.<br /><br />\\"Uncle Johnny\\" is a dark, guitar heavy ballad that really adds a edgy mood to the album...which is overall very optomistic...a huge departure from Hot Fuss which was very dard and pesimistic.  Great song<br /><br />\\"Bones\\" the second single to be released and another gem.  Its kind of an eiry-tune with a trumpet blowing chorus...very catchy and a lot of fun.  You will be sure to love it.<br /><br />\\"My list\\" is a slow building song that ends up becoming very catchy towards the end of the song...a really cool, fresh song.<br /><br />\\"This river is wild\\" and \\"Why do I keep counting?\\" are both very fun laid back songs that take the album into kind of a friendly direction that adds to the overall feel of the album.<br /><br />The album ends with \\"Exilude\\" which is very reminicent of the Beatles Sgt. Pepper's lonely hearts club band with the band singing once again \\"we hope you enjoyed your stay, it was good to have you with us even if its just for the day, outside the sun is shining feels like heaven ain't far away\\".<br /><br />All and all a great demonstration of the talent this young band has, as well as guts.  Many band never do a \\"concept\\" album...let alone one for a follow up sophmore album.  The reason is that many \\"concept\\" albums escape the realms of normal \\"singles\\" music in exchange for a crazy adventure.  Only difference with the Killers \\"concept\\" is that they actually made all the songs sound great.  Buy this album and you will not be disappointed.rus...very chordal.
